concepts.concept_name: Natural indicators and their colour changes
Neutral substances and pH scale introduction

in_scope: Natural indicators: litmus, turmeric, china rose
Litmus paper: red and blue
Acids turn blue litmus red
Bases turn red litmus blue
Turmeric turns red/brown with bases
China rose turns green with bases and dark pink with acids
Common acids: vinegar, lemon juice, curd, hydrochloric acid
Common bases: baking soda, soap, lime water, sodium hydroxide
Properties of acids: sour taste, corrosive
Properties of bases: bitter taste, soapy feel
Neutralisation: acid + base → salt + water
Applications of neutralisation: antacid, soil treatment, factory waste
Neutral substances: water, common salt
Introduction to pH scale concept
out_of_scope: Strong and weak acid/base classification — Introduced in Class 10
pH scale numerical calculations — Introduced in Class 10
Chemical formulae of acids and bases — Introduced in Class 10
Detailed chemical equations for neutralisation — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Differences between physical and chemical changes
Rusting of iron and methods of prevention

in_scope: Physical change: no new substance formed, reversible
Examples: melting of ice, dissolving sugar, tearing paper
Chemical change: new substance formed, generally irreversible
Examples: burning of paper, rusting of iron, cooking food
Signs of chemical change: colour change, gas evolution, heat/light, precipitate
Reversibility as key difference
Rusting: iron + oxygen + water → iron oxide (rust)
Prevention of rusting: painting, oiling, galvanisation, alloying
Galvanisation: coating iron with zinc
Crystallisation: formation of crystals from solution
Crystallisation of copper sulphate and alum
out_of_scope: Balanced chemical equations — Introduced in Class 8
Types of chemical reactions (combination, decomposition) — Introduced in Class 8
Oxidation and reduction in detail — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Animal fibres: wool and its processing
Types of silk and wool-yielding animals

in_scope: Animal fibres: wool and silk
Wool-yielding animals: sheep, goat, yak, camel, llama
Breeds of sheep: Lohi, Rampur Bushair, Nali, Bakharwal, Marwari
Processing of wool: shearing, scouring, sorting, dyeing, spinning, weaving
Sorter's disease caused by anthrax bacteria
Silk moth life cycle: egg, larva (silkworm/caterpillar), pupa (cocoon), adult moth
Sericulture: rearing of silkworms
Reeling: unwinding silk from cocoons
Types of silk: mulberry silk, tassar silk, eri silk, mooga silk
Difference between natural and synthetic fibres (basic)
out_of_scope: Synthetic fibres and polymers — Introduced in Class 8
Chemical structure of fibres — Introduced in Class 8
Industrial textile manufacturing — Introduced in Class 8
Plant fibres (cotton, jute) in detail — Covered in Class 6

concepts.concept_name: Water distribution on Earth and freshwater scarcity

in_scope: About 71% of Earth's surface is covered with water
Only about 3% of total water is freshwater
Most freshwater is locked in ice caps and glaciers
Less than 1% of freshwater is available for use
Water cycle: evaporation, condensation, precipitation, collection
Groundwater: water stored below the ground surface
Water table: upper level of groundwater
Factors affecting water table: rainfall, usage, deforestation
Depletion of water table: causes and effects
Water harvesting: rooftop rainwater harvesting
Methods of water conservation: drip irrigation, repairing leaks, reuse
Bawris (stepwells) as traditional water harvesting systems
Water management and its importance
Effects of water scarcity on communities
out_of_scope: Chemical properties of water — Introduced in Class 8
Water purification methods in detail — Introduced in Class 8
Water pollution and treatment — Introduced in Class 8
Detailed hydrology and aquifers — Introduced in Class 9
